questions.question: What is the most common cause of postmenopausal bleeding?
A 58-year-old, postmenopausal woman presented with bleeding PV. Hysteroscopic biopsyrevealed complex endometrial hyperplasia with atypia. What is the risk of progression of thiscondition to cancer?
questions.explanation: Complex hyperplasia with atypia has a 29% increased risk of progression to endometrial cancer. Ithas the highest risk of progressing to carcinoma compared to other varieties of endometrialhyperplasia.The risk of endometrial hyperplasia progressing to cancer is tabulated below.Type of hyperplasiaProgression to cancerSimple without atypia1%Complex without atyp 3%iaSimple with atypia8%Complex with atypia29%

questions.question: Which is the most common benign cause of pyometra?
questions.explanation: The most common cause of pyometra is senile endometritis.Pyometra refers the collection of pus in the uterus. The most common cancer that causespyometra is carcinoma cervix followed by carcinoma endometrium.

questions.question: Which among the following is an ideal treatment for a 55-year-old female with simplehyperplasia of the endometrium with atypia?
questions.explanation: Simple hysterectomy is the best treatment in a case of atypical endometrial hyperplasia in aperi-menopausal and post-menopausal female.Endometrial hyperplasia with atypia carries 29% risk of developing into endometrial carcinomaand hence, must be treated with total abdominal hysterectomy (simple hysterectomy).856The presence of any concomitant endometrial cancer must be ruled out by doing fractionalcurettage (or dilatation and curettage) before doing a hysterectomy.If a premenopausal woman does not desire to undergo hysterectomy, progesterone can be givenand the patient is followed up every 3-6 months. If the atypia persists during the follow-uphysterectomy should be performed.The table below summarizes the management of patients with endometrial hyperplasiaManagement of EndometrialhyperplasiaHyperplasia without atypiaPre-menopausal womenPostmenopausal women:Simple hyperplasia without atypiaComplex hyperplasia without atypiaHyperplasia with atypiaPre-menopausal womenPeri-menopausal womenPost-menopausal womenProgesterone therapyFollow up without therapyProgesterone therapyIf patient wishes to preserveuterus,give High-dose progesterone therapyIf atypia persists, then perform Total abdominal hysterectomyTotal abdominal hysterectomyTotal abdominal hysterectomy +BSO (bilateral salphingo-ophorectomy)

questions.question: What is the minimum endometrial thickness on transvaginal ultrasonography, above whichyou perform a biopsy in a case of postmenopausal bleeding?
questions.explanation: A finding of endometrial thickness ≥ 4 mm (according to ACOG) in a postmenopausalwomen requires further evaluation, such as endometrial biopsy.If the endometrial thickness is ≤4 mm in a post menopausal female, malignancy is rare and hence,can be managed by tranexamic acid. If the bleeding still persists, the patient needs to undergofractional curettage and hysteroscopy.The algorithm for next step for abnormal uterine bleeding in different age groups is as follows:Age groupAge <40yearsAge>40 years or Age >45 yearsEndometrial thickness on TActionVS>12mm857Endometrial sampling/Endometrial biopsyEndometrial sampling/Endometrial biopsy is done irrespective of usg findingsAge groupEndometrial thickness on TActionVSPost menopausal women≥4mmPost menopausal women<4mmEndometrial sampling/Endometrial biopsyReassurance+tranexamic acidIf, bleeding still persists then do endometrial biopsyEvaluation of postmenopausal bleedingPostmenopausal bleeding orunscheduled bleeding on HRTHistory and examinationTransvaginalultrasoundEndometrialthickness (ET)4mm, no otherabnormalityDischarge, vaginalestrogen if atrophicvaginits presentRRCET-4mm/suspected mass/polypPipellebiopsyUnable topass pipelle/InadequatesampleBenignHyperplasia/cancerHysteroscopyDischarge,vaginal estrogenif atrophicvaginitis presentFollowappropriateguidelineOMARROW

questions.question: What is the most common histopathological variety of endometrial cancer?
questions.explanation: The most common variety of endometrial cancer is adenocarcinoma.The other varieties of endometrial cancer are squamous cell, clear cell, and serous. The mostmalignant varieties are clear cell carcinoma and papillary serous tumor.

questions.question: Which of the following predisposes a patient to develop type 2 carcinoma endometrium?
questions.explanation: Type 2 carcinoma endometrium is commonly seen in menopausal women with atrophicendometrium.Histological classification of endometrial cancer:Note: Type 1 (estrogen-dependent) endometrial CA is the more common type.Type 1 (Endometrioid)Estrogen dependentOccurs in Pre- and Peri-menopausal womenType 2 (Nonendometriod)Estrogen independentOccurs in post-menopausal women858Type 1 (Endometrioid)Hyperplasia presentGood prognosisAssociated with PTEN/KRASmutationType 2 (Nonendometriod)Hyperplasia absentPoor prognosisAssociated with p53 mutation

questions.question: Which of the following constitute corpus cancer syndrome?
questions.explanation: Corpus cancer syndrome constitutes of:• Diabetes mellitus•Obesity.⚫ Hypertension•Cancer of the body of the uterus.Etiology of endometrial carcinoma: (Mnemonic: Family Has OLD AUNTI)Family history•Hypertension•Obesity• Late menopause/Early menarche• Diabetes• Atypical endometrial hyperplasia•Unopposed estrogen/increased estrogen → Hormone replacement therapy, fibroid, PCOD• Nulliparous• Tamoxifen therapy (Raloxifene has no genito-urinary action)• Infertility/irregular menses.Protective factors against endometrial carcinoma include the use of OCPs, smoking, andmultiparity.

questions.question: A gynecologist is performing the following procedure in a woman with postmenopausalbleeding. Identify it.
questions.explanation: The image depicts saline infusion sonography (SIS), also known as sonohysterography. It isusually done after a transvaginal ultrasound, to assess the detailed anatomy of the uterine cavity.In this procedure, a balloon catheter is inserted through the cervix and the endometrial cavity isdistended with 20-40ml of sterile saline. The balloon is inflated to block the backflow of theinfused sterile saline and transvaginal ultrasound is performed to visualize the cavity.It is used:859• To determine the endometrial thickness• To determine the cause in cases of infertility.To identify Mullerian anomalies•To visualize endometrial polyps and pedunculated fibroidsThe image given below shows the appearance of the uterus on SIS.Option A: Transvaginal ultrasound is the initial evaluation for postmenopausal bleeding.Option B: In balloon endometrial ablation, a balloon is inserted into the uterus and inflated withglycine or 5% glucose. It is then heated up, and the endometrium is ablated by the tamponadeeffect.Option D: In hysterosalpingography, contrast dye is inserted into the uterus via a catheter, andthe uterine and fallopian tube anatomy is visualized.

questions.question: A menopausal patient suspected to have endometrial carcinoma is undergoing a transvaginalultrasound. Which of the following findings would be inconsistent with her diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Decreased vascular resistance with increased tumor vascularity is seen in carcinomaendometrium.USG findings in carcinoma endometrium include:•Endometrial thickness >4 mm in postmenopausal women and >10 mm in perimenopausalwomen•Hyperechoic endometrium with irregular outlines• Increased tumor vascularity with low vascular resistance•Fluid in uterine cavity860

questions.question: A 52-year-old woman with postmenopausal bleeding has an endometrial thickness of 7 mmon ultrasound. What is the next step in her management?
questions.explanation: The next line of management in a patient with increased endometrial thickness is an endometrialbiopsy.In a postmenopausal woman, the normal endometrium should not exceed 4 mm in thickness. If itexceeds 4 mm, then histopathological examination (HPE) of the endometrium is mandatory,irrespective of the presence or absence of symptoms. In a perimenopausal woman, the cutoff fornormal endometrial thickness is 10mm.Hysteroscopy and biopsy is preferred over other blind curettage methods for HPE. A biopsy ismade from suspicious areas after visualization so chances of missing the lesion are reduced.

questions.question: A 54-year-old woman with postmenopausal bleeding is suspected to have an endometriallesion. What is the gold standard investigation to confirm her diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Hysteroscopic inspection and selective biopsy is now considered the gold standard in thediagnosis of an endometrial lesion. It is preferred for the initial evaluation of women withbleeding suspicious for malignancy.Endometrial sampling can be done by hysteroscopic biopsy. It is more sensitive for focalendometrial lesions. Dilatation and curettage may also aid the sampling of endometrial lesions.Ultrasound, CT, and MRI are adjuvant to other investigations. Diagnostic laparoscopy will berequired to study the nature of the tumor and its spread if ultrasound picks up a pelvic tumor.The image given below shows the procedure of hysteroscopy.HysteroscopyHysteroscopeSpeculumVaginaCervixUterus

questions.question: A 62-year-old woman presents with vaginal bleeding 11 years after she had attainedmenopause. An endometrial biopsy reveals adenocarcinoma. What is the gold standardmethod for staging her condition?
questions.explanation: The given scenario depicts endometrial carcinoma and the gold standard method for staging thiscondition is surgery.861According to FIGO/TNM classification system, a total hysterectomy with bilateralsalpingo-oophorectomy and pelvic and para-aortic lymph node dissection is the standard stagingprocedure for endometrial cancer.Option A: Contrast-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) appears to be the bestradiographic modality for detecting myometrial invasion or cervical involvement.Option C: Hysteroscopy visualizes the entire uterine lining and a biopsy is taken from suspiciousareas. This is not 100% predictive, as an early lesion can be missed. Recently, the concern hasbeen raised regarding the spilling of cancer cells into the peritoneal cavity during hysteroscopy.Option D: PET-CT reveals metabolic activity in the tissue and is highly sensitive and specific fordetecting positive pelvic and/or para-aortic lymphadenopathy as well as distant metastases inselected high-risk patients with endometrial cancer.

questions.question: Which lymph nodes are most commonly involved in patients with endometrial carcinoma?
questions.explanation: Pelvic and para-aortic lymph nodes are commonly involved in endometrial cancer.The spread is through the infundibulopelvic ligament.Rarely, inguinal & femoral lymph nodes are involved.

questions.question: A patient presented with carcinoma endometrium involving >50% myometrium, extendingto the vagina but with no involvement of para-aortic and pre aortic nodes. What is the stageof her disease?
questions.explanation: Carcinoma endometrium involving the vagina but having no lymph node involvement is classifiedas stage IIIB.

questions.question: Which of the following is indicated for the treatment of a patient with early endometrialcancer?

options.A: Hysterectomy, B/L salpingo-oophorectomy, lymph node sampling

questions.explanation: Early endometrial cancer (stages I & II) is primarily managed surgically. The surgeryperformed here is abdominal hysterectomy, B/L salpingo-oophorectomy, omentectomy and pelvic& para-aortic lymph node sampling.Postoperative management of endometrial cancer:In low-risk endometrial cancer, no further treatment is required.In intermediate-risk, radiotherapy is done.In high risk, chemotherapy + radiotherapy is done.

questions.question: A woman with endometrial carcinoma is undergoing radiotherapy. Which of the following istrue?

options.A: Intensity is inversely proportional to squared distance
options.B: Small blood vessels are most radioresistant
options.C: Rapidly proliferating cells are most radioresistant

questions.explanation: The intensity of radiation is inversely proportional to the squared distance. This is known as theinverse square law in radiotherapy.862Chemoradiation is the mainstay of treatment of stage III and IV endometrial cancers. They aretreated with brachytherapy followed by external radiation. Brachytherapy is a form of radiationtherapy in which the radiation source is placed close to the tumor.Other options:Option B: Larger blood vessels are more radioresistant than microvasculature.Option C: Permanent non-dividing cells are more radioresistant than rapidly proliferating cells.Option D: Small intestinal epithelial cells (intestinal crypts), which divide rapidly with nodifferentiation are the most radiosensitive.

questions.question: Which among the following is the mainstay of treatment in a patient diagnosed with Stage IIIendometrial cancer?854
questions.explanation: Chemotherapy is the mainstay of treatment in Stage III endometrial cancer.In order to stage carcinoma endometrium, total abdominal hysterectomy with bilateralsalpingo-Oophorectomy and lymphadenectomy is done (surgical staging).Thus the management, once staging is done, is mainly postoperative. Up to stage II, radiotherapycan be given. Stages III & IV are managed by chemotherapy such as doxorubicin,cisplatin, and paclitaxel.Note: Stage III is said to be inoperable but debulking surgery is sometimes attempted. However,the mainstay of treatment for stage III disease remains chemotherapy.863
